About I work at the intersection of semantics, pragmatics, and prosody, with a focus on how intonation and discourse particles shape speech acts, especially in expressions of surprise. On the computational side, I focus on human-centered, ethical, and transparent use of data in AI research. My recent work looks at how to use human feedback to improve model evaluations, with an emphasis on curating meaningful data and aligning model behavior with real-world contexts and user needs.
I’m an Assistant Professor of Computational Linguistics at San José State University. Before that, I received my PhD in Linguistics from UC Santa Cruz, and spent time in the tech industry working as a Linguist and Data Scientist for Google, Amazon, and Cisco.

content:
Human-In-The-Loop AI Evaluation Recently, my research has focused on how to integrate human feedback into training and evaluating large language models, with a focus on improving performance and ensuring alignment with user preferences in real-world contexts. This work demonstrates the limitations of automated metrics in capturing nuance, especially in sensitive tasks like summarization or toxicity detection, and proposes human-centered methodologies that prioritize meaningful evaluation and data curation.

A central theme is understanding how these elements, especially in expressions of surprise, function to modify the speech act itself across different languages.
